http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Compilation of terms that described geometry (i.e. the shape, distribution and configuration) of alteration in rocks and minerals as observed at the macro-, meso- and microscopic scale, and applying to the specific area of observation. Alteration in this context is defined as a modification of the original lithology caused by meteoric, connate, metamorphic, or magmatic-derived fluids, excluding the weathering environment, mineralization and direct magmatic or metamorphic processes. Definitions are largely taken from Pirajno (2009) and the Glossary of geology (Neuendorf et al., 2011).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value:
Derived from GSWA's WAROX database's table  [GEOLOGY].[WAROX.REF].[AltForm], and expanded to include additional terms. Definitions compiled from:
1) Neuendorf, KKE, Mehl Jr, JP and Jackson, JA (editors) 2011, Glossary of geology (5th edition, revised): American Geosciences Institute, Alexandria, Virginia, USA, 800p.
2) Pirajno, F 2009, Hydrothermal processes and mineral systems: Springer-Verlag, 1250p.
3) Thompson, JFH, Thompson, AJB and Allen, RL 1996, Atlas of alteration: A field and petrographic guide to hydrothermal alteration minerals, St. John's, Nfld: Geological Association of Canada, Mineral Deposits Division, 119p.

Alteration in this context is defined as a modification of the original lithology caused by meteoric, connate, metamorphic, or magmatic-derived fluids, excluding the weathering environment, mineralization and direct magmatic or metamorphic processes. Definitions are largely taken from Pirajno (2009) and the Glossary of geology (Neuendorf et al., 2011).
